title: 106_hr605
content: The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254 of title 38, United States Code. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the recall of retired judges. The "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999" allows the recall of retired judges for further service on the Court in accordance with specific criteria. Retired judges must provide written notice of their availability and willingness to be recalled, which is irrevocable. Recall-eligible retired judges are those who meet the criteria outlined in the Act. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims Act of 1999 allows the recall of retired judges for further service on the Court. Retired judges must provide written notice of their availability and willingness to be recalled. The chief judge may recall a retired judge for up to 90 days per calendar year, not to exceed 180 days total. Retired judges can be recalled for up to 90 days per calendar year, not exceeding 180 days total. If a recalled judge declines to serve (except due to disability), they will be removed from recall eligibility. A permanently disabled recalled judge will also lose recall eligibility. Recalled judges have the same powers and duties as active judges. A retired judge recalled under this section may exercise all powers and duties of an active judge. The pay for a recalled judge varies based on retirement status, and recalled judges who retired under specific chapters of title 5 are considered reemployed annuitants. A retired judge recalled under this section may exercise all powers and duties of an active judge and is considered a reemployed annuitant under chapter 83 or 84 of title 5. SEC. 4 amends Section 7296(b) of title 38, United States Code, to only credit years of service as a judge of the Court for calculating an individual's service. Fractional parts of a year less than 183 days are disregarded, while 183 days or more are credited as a full year. SEC. 5 addresses judges' retired pay. SEC. 5 amends Section 7296 of title 38, United States Code, regarding judges' retired pay. It specifies different pay rates based on recall eligibility and notice of availability for service in a recalled status. The retired pay of a judge is based on recall eligibility and availability for service in a recalled status. Cost-of-living adjustments apply to retired pay only in certain cases to prevent excess payments. Cost-of-living adjustments for retired judges are limited to prevent excess payments based on the annual rate of pay for chief judges and judges of the court. This is to ensure that retired pay does not exceed the specified rates. Retired judges' pay adjustments are limited to prevent excess payments based on their annual rate of pay. Military retired pay for judges is suspended during active service on the court but resumes without reduction upon retirement. SEC. 6 introduces a limitation on activities of retired judges regarding representing clients in veterans' benefits claims, leading to a forfeiture of retired pay. SEC. 7 discusses early retirement authority for current judges to stagger terms. Retirement is authorized for eligible judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims who meet specific criteria, including age, years of service, and retirement pay election. If multiple judges qualify in a year, the most senior judge can retire. Judges must provide notice to retire in a specific year. In accordance with subsection (d), the most senior judge of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims eligible to retire in a specific year must provide written notice to the President and chief judge by April 1 of that year. The retirement date specified in the notice is irrevocable, and the judge will be retired during the fiscal year in which the notice is provided, not earlier than 90 days after the notice date. A judge eligible to retire must provide notice by April 1, with retirement date being irrevocable. The retired judge is considered under section 7296(b)(1) of title 38, United States Code, and the rate of retired pay is determined based on years of service. The retired pay for judges is calculated based on their years of service and age, with adjustments available for recall-eligible retired judges. An amendment is made to the duty of the actuary under section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code. An amendment is made to the duty of the actuary under section 7298(e)(2) of title 38, United States Code, regarding the calculation of retired pay for judges, including adjustments for recall-eligible retired judges.
